There may be some underlying issues in Colin's biped domain that I'm not =
aware of, but from my experience so far I think this would be a great domai=
n for trying novelty search.  Colin did say it didn't work so well to make =
it open-ended (which might mean something more like novelty search), but at=
 least our group has found novelty search is often better for these types o=
f walking domains.  We basically always use it now for evolving walkers and=
 it seems to be create nicer gaits in general.  It does have to be set up w=
ith care, but my guess is that it would lead to nicer walkers.  You can see=
 the comparison movie with the 3-D biped from fitness and novelty here:

ht=
tp://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/noveltysearch/biped_compare.avi

ken

--- In neat@yah=
oogroups.com, "krn_2k" <krn_2k@...> wrote:
>
> > Regarding the walker, any =
advice on improving the fitness function?
> 
> Hi Colin,
>    Have you cons=
idered using novelty search for the Bipedal Walker? (From Ken Stanley's "Ab=
andoning objectives: evolution through the search for novelty alone" paper,=
 abstract: in "biped walking tasks.. novelty search significantly outperfor=
ms objective-based search...").
> 
> Would Novelty search be easy to add to=
 SharpNeat or would it require significant structural changes to SharpNEAT =
to get going? Assuming the use of an existing fast Key/Value store nosql DB=
 for behaviour storage and KNN lookups, similar to this one:
> http://www.c=
odeproject.com/Articles/316816/RaptorDB-The-Key-Value-Store-V2
> 
> I only =
ask as I am curious to try novelty search out for a while on some of the ex=
isting SharpNEAT example projects (but as yet have not found the time to lo=
ok into it).
> 
> Regards,
> Keith Nelson
>

 Colin Green <colin.green1@> wrote:

lso a few fixes

, some fairly

 completely
> > broken (it works a lot better now!). Will aim to make packa=
ge up a new
> > SharpNEAT release 7zip soon.

> > Regarding the walker,=
 any advice on improving the fitness function?
> > This one has stop condit=
ions for when one or both of the feet are too
> > high, the torso height go=
es below a threshold or any of the the joint
> > angles go beyond 90 degree=
s. Ideally I'd like to avoid these and make
> > it more open ended (and pun=
ish for applied torque to get efficient
> > walkers) but the reality was th=
at that didn't seem to work very well.

> > Regards,
